policies.name: System and Communications Protection Policy
policies.description: Organizational policy governing boundary protection, network security architecture, and managed interface requirements
policies.rationale: NIST 03.13.01 requires monitoring and controlling communications at managed interfaces and implementing boundary protection devices arranged in accordance with organizational security architecture

policies.name: Network Security Policy
policies.description: Policy defining requirements for network segmentation, DMZ implementation, and boundary device deployment
policies.rationale: Control requires implementing subnetworks for publicly accessible components that are physically or logically separated from internal networks

procedures.name: Boundary Device Management Procedure
procedures.description: Step-by-step process for deploying, configuring, and maintaining firewalls, routers, gateways, and other boundary protection devices
procedures.rationale: Control requires connecting to external systems only through managed interfaces consisting of boundary protection devices

procedures.name: DMZ Configuration Procedure
procedures.description: Process for implementing and maintaining demilitarized zones for publicly accessible system components
procedures.rationale: NIST discussion states subnetworks must be physically or logically separated from internal networks

procedures.name: Network Traffic Monitoring Procedure
procedures.description: Process for monitoring and controlling communications at external and key internal managed interfaces
procedures.rationale: Control explicitly requires monitoring and controlling communications at managed interfaces

executionEvidence.name: Firewall Rule Review Reports
executionEvidence.description: Monthly reports showing: firewall rules reviewed, unauthorized rules removed, rule justifications verified, reviewer signatures, date completed
executionEvidence.rationale: Demonstrates ongoing monitoring and control of communications at boundary devices per 03.13.01.a

executionEvidence.name: Network Traffic Analysis Logs
executionEvidence.description: Daily logs showing: monitored traffic at managed interfaces, detected anomalies, blocked spoofed traffic, alert responses, traffic patterns analyzed
executionEvidence.rationale: NIST discussion requires restricting traffic that appears to be spoofing internal/external addresses

executionEvidence.name: Boundary Device Configuration Audits
executionEvidence.description: Quarterly audits showing: boundary devices inventoried, configurations validated against security architecture, deviations identified, remediation completed
executionEvidence.rationale: Validates that boundary protection devices are arranged in accordance with organizational security architecture per 03.13.01.c

executionEvidence.name: DMZ Segregation Verification Reports
executionEvidence.description: Quarterly reports showing: publicly accessible components identified, network segregation verified, unauthorized connections blocked, segmentation effectiveness tested
executionEvidence.rationale: Demonstrates implementation of subnetworks that are physically or logically separated from internal networks per 03.13.01.b

operationalActivities: Monitor communications at external managed interfaces continuously
Control communications at key internal managed interfaces
Review and update firewall rules monthly
Verify DMZ segregation from internal networks quarterly
Analyze network traffic for spoofing attempts daily
Audit boundary device configurations quarterly
Test network segmentation effectiveness quarterly
Block unauthorized connections to external systems

policies.name: System and Communications Protection Policy
policies.description: Organizational policy governing object reuse, residual information protection, and shared resource management
policies.rationale: NIST 03.13.04 requires preventing unauthorized information transfer via shared system resources, which is referred to as object reuse and residual information protection

policies.name: Data Sanitization Policy
policies.description: Policy defining requirements for clearing information from shared resources before reallocation
policies.rationale: Control requires stopping information from prior users being available to current users after resources are released back to the system

procedures.name: Object Reuse Procedure
procedures.description: Step-by-step process for sanitizing shared system resources including memory, storage, and processing resources before reallocation
procedures.rationale: Control requires preventing information from prior users/roles from being available to current users/roles

procedures.name: Memory Sanitization Procedure
procedures.description: Technical process for securely clearing memory buffers, caches, and temporary storage when released
procedures.rationale: NIST discussion states information in shared system resources includes encrypted representations requiring protection

procedures.name: Device Wipe Procedure
procedures.description: Process for wiping mobile devices and shared workstations when reassigned to new users
procedures.rationale: Ensures prior user information is not available to subsequent users on shared devices

executionEvidence.name: Resource Deallocation Logs
executionEvidence.description: Continuous logs showing: resources released, sanitization method applied, verification of successful clearing, timestamp, next allocation recorded
executionEvidence.rationale: Demonstrates that shared resources are sanitized before reallocation per 03.13.04

executionEvidence.name: Memory Sanitization Verification Reports
executionEvidence.description: Quarterly reports showing: sanitization mechanisms tested, memory clearing verified, residual data checks performed, failures addressed
executionEvidence.rationale: Validates effectiveness of mechanisms preventing unauthorized information transfer via shared resources

executionEvidence.name: Device Wipe Completion Records
executionEvidence.description: Records showing: device identification, wipe method used, wipe completion verified, reassignment authorized, date completed
executionEvidence.rationale: Proves prior user information is removed before device reassignment

operationalActivities: Sanitize memory buffers when released from processes
Clear temporary storage before reallocation
Wipe devices completely when reassigned to new users
Verify sanitization mechanisms quarterly
Test memory clearing effectiveness quarterly
Log all resource deallocation and sanitization activities
Monitor for residual information leakage

controls.controlTitle: Network Communications – Deny by Default – Allow by Exception

policies.name: Network Security Policy
policies.description: Organizational policy establishing deny-all, allow-by-exception network communications traffic requirements
policies.rationale: NIST 03.13.06 requires denying network communications traffic by default and allowing by exception to ensure only essential connections are permitted

policies.name: Firewall Management Policy
policies.description: Policy defining requirements for implementing default-deny posture and exception approval processes
policies.rationale: Control requires implementing deny-all policy at system boundary and identified internal points

procedures.name: Firewall Rule Approval Procedure
procedures.description: Step-by-step process for requesting, reviewing, approving, and documenting exceptions to default-deny policy
procedures.rationale: Control requires allowing network communications by exception, necessitating formal approval process

procedures.name: Connection Whitelist Management Procedure
procedures.description: Process for maintaining and reviewing approved network connections and services
procedures.rationale: NIST discussion states policy ensures only essential and approved connections are allowed

procedures.name: Default-Deny Configuration Procedure
procedures.description: Technical process for configuring firewalls, ACLs, and network devices with default-deny rules
procedures.rationale: Control requires implementing deny-all policy at inbound and outbound network traffic points

executionEvidence.name: Firewall Rule Change Logs
executionEvidence.description: Continuous logs showing: rule change requested, business justification provided, approver identification, rule implemented, date completed
executionEvidence.rationale: Demonstrates that exceptions to default-deny are formally approved per 03.13.06

executionEvidence.name: Approved Connections List Reviews
executionEvidence.description: Quarterly reports showing: all allowed connections reviewed, business need revalidated, unnecessary exceptions removed, approvals renewed
executionEvidence.rationale: Ensures only essential and approved connections remain allowed per NIST discussion

executionEvidence.name: Default-Deny Verification Reports
executionEvidence.description: Monthly reports showing: default-deny policy tested, unauthorized traffic blocked, exceptions validated, policy effectiveness verified
executionEvidence.rationale: Validates that deny-all, allow-by-exception policy is effectively implemented

executionEvidence.name: Blocked Connection Reports
executionEvidence.description: Weekly reports showing: denied connection attempts, source/destination analysis, attack patterns identified, false positives reviewed
executionEvidence.rationale: Demonstrates default-deny posture is blocking unauthorized traffic as required

operationalActivities: Configure all network devices with default-deny rules
Review and approve exceptions to default-deny policy
Test default-deny policy effectiveness monthly
Review approved connections list quarterly
Remove unnecessary exceptions quarterly
Log all denied connection attempts
Analyze blocked traffic patterns weekly
Validate firewall rules against approved exceptions monthly

policies.name: Cryptographic Protection Policy
policies.description: Organizational policy establishing requirements for cryptographic mechanisms to protect CUI during transmission and while in storage
policies.rationale: NIST 03.13.08 requires implementing cryptographic mechanisms to prevent unauthorized disclosure of CUI during transmission and storage

policies.name: Data Protection Policy
policies.description: Policy defining encryption requirements for CUI across all system components including endpoints, servers, mobile devices, and network communications
policies.rationale: Control applies to internal and external networks and any system components that can transmit or store CUI

procedures.name: Encryption Implementation Procedure
procedures.description: Step-by-step process for implementing encryption on servers, workstations, mobile devices, storage devices, and databases containing CUI
procedures.rationale: Control requires protecting CUI in storage which resides on internal/external storage devices, storage area networks, and databases

procedures.name: TLS/IPsec Configuration Procedure
procedures.description: Technical process for configuring and maintaining TLS for web communications and IPsec for network-level encryption
procedures.rationale: NIST discussion specifies TLS and IPsec as cryptographic mechanisms protecting CUI confidentiality during transmission

procedures.name: Full Disk Encryption Procedure
procedures.description: Process for deploying and managing BitLocker or equivalent full disk encryption on endpoints and servers
procedures.rationale: Protects information at rest on desktop computers, notebook computers, and mobile devices per control requirements

executionEvidence.name: Encryption Verification Scans
executionEvidence.description: Monthly scans showing: all devices inventoried, encryption status verified, unencrypted CUI storage identified, remediation completed
executionEvidence.rationale: Demonstrates cryptographic mechanisms are protecting CUI in storage per 03.13.08

executionEvidence.name: TLS Certificate Validation Reports
executionEvidence.description: Quarterly reports showing: TLS certificates inventoried, expiration dates verified, weak ciphers identified, certificate renewals completed
executionEvidence.rationale: Validates TLS cryptographic mechanisms protecting CUI during transmission are properly maintained

executionEvidence.name: Encrypted Storage Inventory
executionEvidence.description: Quarterly inventory showing: all CUI storage locations identified, encryption method documented, compliance verified, gaps remediated
executionEvidence.rationale: NIST requires encryption of information at rest on all storage devices containing CUI

executionEvidence.name: Network Traffic Encryption Reports
executionEvidence.description: Weekly reports showing: network traffic analyzed, unencrypted CUI transmission detected, IPsec/TLS enforcement verified, violations addressed
executionEvidence.rationale: Control requires preventing unauthorized disclosure during transmission on internal and external networks

operationalActivities: Deploy full disk encryption on all endpoints and servers storing CUI
Configure TLS for all web-based CUI transmissions
Implement IPsec for network-level CUI protection
Verify encryption status on all devices monthly
Scan network traffic for unencrypted CUI weekly
Review and update TLS certificates quarterly
Inventory all CUI storage locations quarterly
Remediate unencrypted CUI storage within 30 days of discovery

policies.name: Session Management Policy
policies.description: Organizational policy defining requirements for terminating network connections after session completion or defined inactivity periods
policies.rationale: NIST 03.13.09 requires terminating network connections associated with communications sessions at end of session or after organization-defined inactivity period

policies.name: Network Security Policy
policies.description: Policy establishing inactivity timeout periods by network access type and specific network accesses
policies.rationale: NIST discussion states time periods of inactivity may be established by type of network access or for specific network accesses

procedures.name: Session Timeout Configuration Procedure
procedures.description: Step-by-step process for configuring network connection timeouts on firewalls, VPN concentrators, application servers, and network devices
procedures.rationale: Control requires terminating connections at operating system level or application level after defined inactivity

procedures.name: Network Session Termination Procedure
procedures.description: Technical process for deallocating TCP/IP addresses, port pairs, and networking assignments when sessions end
procedures.rationale: NIST discussion specifies termination includes deallocating TCP/IP addresses or port pairs at OS level or networking assignments at application level

executionEvidence.name: Session Timeout Configuration Audits
executionEvidence.description: Quarterly audits showing: timeout configurations inventoried, inactivity periods validated against policy, non-compliant systems identified, remediation completed
executionEvidence.rationale: Validates that organization-defined inactivity timeouts are configured per 03.13.09

executionEvidence.name: Terminated Session Logs
executionEvidence.description: Daily logs showing: sessions terminated due to inactivity, session duration recorded, resource deallocation verified, user notified
executionEvidence.rationale: Demonstrates network connections are being terminated after inactivity as required

executionEvidence.name: Inactive Connection Reports
executionEvidence.description: Weekly reports showing: long-running connections identified, inactive sessions detected, automatic termination verified, timeout policy effectiveness
executionEvidence.rationale: Monitors effectiveness of session termination mechanisms across internal and external networks

operationalActivities: Configure session timeouts on all network access points
Set VPN connection inactivity timeout to 15 minutes
Configure application session timeouts based on risk level
Monitor and log all session terminations daily
Review inactive connection patterns weekly
Audit timeout configurations quarterly
Verify TCP/IP resource deallocation on session end
Test session timeout enforcement quarterly

policies.name: Cryptographic Key Management Policy
policies.description: Organizational policy establishing requirements for key generation, distribution, storage, access, and destruction in accordance with federal laws and regulations
policies.rationale: NIST 03.13.10 requires establishing and managing cryptographic keys per organization-defined requirements for key lifecycle management

policies.name: Key Lifecycle Management Policy
policies.description: Policy defining specific requirements for cryptographic key establishment and management including FIPS compliance
policies.rationale: Organizations must satisfy requirements in accordance with applicable federal laws, Executive Orders, policies, directives, regulations, and standards

procedures.name: Key Generation Procedure
procedures.description: Step-by-step process for generating cryptographic keys using FIPS 140-3 validated modules and approved algorithms
procedures.rationale: Control requires establishing cryptographic keys per organization-defined requirements for key generation

procedures.name: Key Distribution Procedure
procedures.description: Technical process for securely distributing cryptographic keys to authorized systems and users
procedures.rationale: Control explicitly requires key distribution requirements as part of key management

procedures.name: Key Storage and Protection Procedure
procedures.description: Process for storing cryptographic keys in Hardware Security Modules (HSMs) or key management systems with appropriate access controls
procedures.rationale: Control requires defining storage requirements; supporting publications reference SP 800-57 key storage guidance

procedures.name: Key Destruction Procedure
procedures.description: Process for securely destroying cryptographic keys at end of lifecycle including verification of destruction
procedures.rationale: Control explicitly requires key destruction requirements as part of key management

executionEvidence.name: Key Generation Logs
executionEvidence.description: Continuous logs showing: key generated, algorithm used, key length, FIPS module validation, purpose documented, timestamp
executionEvidence.rationale: Demonstrates keys are generated per organization-defined requirements per 03.13.10

executionEvidence.name: Key Rotation Records
executionEvidence.description: Quarterly records showing: keys rotated per schedule, old keys retired, new keys distributed, systems updated, rotation completed
executionEvidence.rationale: Key rotation is essential key management requirement per SP 800-57 guidance

executionEvidence.name: Key Destruction Certificates
executionEvidence.description: Records showing: key identification, destruction method used, destruction verified, authorization documented, date completed
executionEvidence.rationale: Proves keys are destroyed per organization-defined requirements

executionEvidence.name: Key Inventory Audits
executionEvidence.description: Annual audits showing: all cryptographic keys inventoried, key metadata verified, unauthorized keys identified, compliance validated
executionEvidence.rationale: Comprehensive inventory validates all keys are managed per established requirements

executionEvidence.name: HSM Access Logs
executionEvidence.description: Continuous logs showing: key access requests, authorized users verified, keys retrieved, operations performed, timestamp
executionEvidence.rationale: Demonstrates key access controls are enforced per organization-defined requirements

operationalActivities: Generate cryptographic keys using FIPS 140-3 validated modules
Store keys in Hardware Security Modules (HSMs) or approved key management systems
Rotate encryption keys quarterly or per policy requirements
Distribute keys securely to authorized systems only
Destroy retired keys using approved destruction methods
Audit key inventory annually
Monitor HSM access logs continuously
Verify key generation uses approved algorithms
Document all key lifecycle events
